answers: Cavalleria Rusticana <Other Fine Arts, DY><ed. AB>
parts: Name this profession shared by many characters in Pagliacci. Rigoletto is a hunchbacked one of these characters that entertains the Duke of Mantua.
After frightening his wife with his vehemence, Canio’s wife Nedda sings this aria about birds “screeching up in the sky.”
Pagliacci is often paired with this other verismo opera by Pietro Mascagni, in which Turiddu and Alfio kill each other in a duel over Lola.

answers: Bobby Fischer <Pop Culture/Mixed Academic, MX and JC><ed. KLu, AK, and AdH>
parts: Name this game played on an eight by eight board between black and white pieces. A win in this game is achieved through checkmating the opposing side’s king.
This computer program developed by Google that learned chess in 4 hours crushed the best chess engine in the world, Stockfish, in a series of 1000 matches in December 2018.

This American chess prodigy defeated Boris Spassky in the World Chess Championships of 1972, ending an era of Soviet dominance. He was the first FIDE world number one player, and wrote My 60 Memorable Games.
Although this wife of Isaac plotted for Jacob to receive his father’s blessing in place of his brother Esau, she did so in order to fulfill the wishes of God.
And while this handmaid of Abraham was cast out into the desert after Sarah believed her to be acting too haughty with her son Ishmael, their emotional tension is arguably non-reductive.
Furthermore in the Book of Joshua, this prostitute of Jericho is hailed as a hero for aiding the Hebrew spies, who reward her by sparing her family when the city is taken.

answers: Aurangzeb [or Muhi-ud-Din Muhammad; accept Alamgir I]
parts: Name this ruler who defeated his brother Dara Shikoh in a civil war and brought the empire he ruled to its greatest extent. He succeeded his father Shah Jahan.

Aurangzeb, his father Shah Jahan, and his great-grandfather Akbar the Great, were rulers of this Indian empire. After Aurangzeb’s son Shah Alam repealed his father’s religious practices, this empire eventually declined.
Akbar the Great notably repealed this tax, which was to be paid by all non-Muslims living in Muslim land.

answers: Golden Gate Bridge <Other History, JB><ed. AH>
parts: Emperor Norton lost most of his fortune (and his sanity) after he failed to corner the market for this commodity that had skyrocketed in price thanks to a famine in China.
Emperor Norton demanded that this man be sent as a prisoner to America. This Emperor, who banned unsanctioned armed groups with his Black Decree, was captured following the Siege of Querétaro.
Emperor Norton repeatedly urged for the construction of a suspension bridge over San Francisco Bay. In 1937, his vision was realized with the completion of this iridescent structure.
Name this experiment that fired a beam of electrons at nickel, creating a diffraction pattern.
The de Broglie equation states that wavelength is equal to this constant divided by momentum. This constant, denoted h, has a reduced form when divided by two pi and will soon define the kilogram.
One form of this inequality states that sigma x times sigma p is greater than or equal to h-bar over two.

answers: Justin Trudeau [prompt on Trudeau; do not accept or prompt on “Pierre Trudeau”]
parts: This Canadian Prime Minister hosted the event. In February 2018, this man controversially used the term “peoplekind” instead of “mankind” in an allusion to feminism.

At the conference, President Trump pushed other leaders to recognize this region as part of Russia. In 2014, Russia annexed this region and incorporated its largest city of Sevastopol as federal subjects.
Twelve heads of states were invited to the conference as part of an Outreach Session, including this man. This man, the current chair of the G20, has been the president of Argentina since 2015.

answers: patients of Sigmund Freud [accept reasonable equivalents such as subjects or case studies; prompt on patients or subjects]
parts: Name these individuals who included “Wolf Man.” Another one of these individuals endured a disastrous nasal surgery, which was explained through the concept of “deferred action.”

The guilt of that botched surgery was catalogued in a work named after these entities. In that work on the interpretation of these things, Freud claimed that these entities were a form of “wish fulfillment.”
Freud stated that dreams consist of manifest content and this other type of content. This sort of content consists of the hidden and suppressed drives of the unconscious.

answers: Gibbons v. Ogden [prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name these items. In Champion v. Ames the Court held that these items could be subject to interstate commerce regulations.

Champion v. Ames built on this 1824 case which established the Court’s plenary power in interstate commerce. This case arose from a steamboat monopoly the state of New York granted to Robert Livingston and Robert Fulton.
Cohens v. Virginia and Gibbons v. Ogden were presided over by this longest serving chief justice who also presided over Marbury v Madison.
Name this macromolecule which, unlike a similar double stranded molecule, does not contain thymine.
This type of RNA is small and noncoding. Along with siRNA, it can be found in an RNA-induced silencing complex, which participates in RNA interference.

miRNAs bind to the untranslated region denoted by [this number]-prime, which is followed by the poly(A) tail. Nucleotides are added to the end of the nucleic acid denoted [this number]-prime, which is attached to an OH group.
An inequality named for this three-sided polygon states that the sum of two of its sides must be greater than the third.

An inequality named for this man and Schwarz gives a lower bound for the sums of the squares of two sets of numbers. This man’s integral theorem states that the line integral on a closed path of a holomorphic function f of z with respect to z is zero.

This man names an inequality with Louis Mordell that relates a point’s distances from a triangle’s sides and vertices. This man’s number describes one’s collaborative distance to him through the co-authorship of papers.

Name this short story in which Shoba and Shukumar rekindle their marriage when their power goes out five nights in succession. This story was published as the first in the collection The Interpreter of Maladies.
The Interpreter of Maladies was written by this author of The Namesake. She recently translated her short story “The Boundary” from Italian for the New Yorker.
Many of Lahiri’s works center around her roots in Calcutta, a city in this country. Other authors from this country include Vikram Seth and Salman Rushdie.

Name this artist who dripped red, white, and blue encaustic over a collage of newspapers, creating 48 waxy stars. One of his depictions of the American flag is on display at the Museum of Modern Art in New York.

Leo Castelli launched Johns’ career by chance while trying to find this artist’s studio. This artist created many combines, including one called Monogram which depicts a stuffed Angora goat passing through a car tire.
Johns and Rauschenberg influenced the rise of this art movement that rejected the highbrow egoism of abstract expressionism. Artists of this movement include Roy Lichtenstein and Andy Warhol.
Oskar Matzerath is the glass-shattering protagonist of this novel, whose title refers to his most prized possession.

The Tin Drum is partially set during this war, which annihilates Oskar’s hometown. Gunter Grass’s memoir Peeling the Onion discusses his service in the Waffen SS, an armed branch of the Nazi Party during this war.
In The Tin Drum, Oskar Matzerath leads this gang of street urchins that conducts raids on the offices of the SS.
Name this son of Uther Pendragon who won the throne of England by drawing a sword from a stone, according to the account of Geoffrey of Monmouth.
In that account, not only does Arthur bring peace to Britain, but he defeats a massive army led by one of these figures named Lucius Tiberius.
The bad fanfictions start to kick off in the 12th century with the French writer Chrétien de Troyes, who decided that this adulterous Lord of Joyous Gard ought to have an affair with Guinevere.
Name this Pisan naval commander who Dante accused of treason in the Divine Comedy. It is ambiguous as to whether he ate his sons.
Ugolino appears in Dante’s Inferno and is found in the 9th Circle of this location, where Satan chews on the bodies of Judas, Brutus, and Cassius.
Dante is guided through Hell by Virgil, who is condemned with all the other righteous pagans to this first circle of Hell traditionally reserved for unbaptized infants.

answers: Philip II of Spain [prompt on Philip]
parts: Name this nation preceded by the Dutch Republic. Its capital is at The Hague, where its king Willem-Alexander resides at Villa Eikenhorst.
The Dutch Revolt began against this Spanish monarch. This monarch appointed the Duke of Alba to suppress dissidents in the Council of Blood and dispatched the Spanish Armada against England.

This city’s brutal sacking in what is known as the “Spanish Fury” united the Netherlands against Habsburg rule. A later battle in this city saw the use of “hellburners” against the army of Alexander Farnese.

answers: Trout Quintet [accept Schubert Piano Quintet in A Major, prompt on partial answer]
parts: This piece was based on a song cautioning young girls to be wary of their seducers. Recurring sextuplet arpeggios in this work evoke the leaping of the title animal.

This Russian composer’s String Quartet No. 8 features his signature DSCH motif and was dedicated “to the victims of fascism and war.” Historians have speculated that the dedication was imposed by Soviet authorities.
This composer of the “Clock” and “Surprise” Symphonies wrote over seventy quartets, and was consequently dubbed the “father of the string quartet.”

answers: Hund’s rule of maximum multiplicity <Chemistry, CT><ed. KLei>
parts: Name this quantity which represents the energy released in the formation of a one minus anion of a gas phase atom.
The electron affinity for this element is about negative seven kilojoules per mole. This element is found in nature as a diatomic molecule with a triple bond that makes up most of the atmosphere.

Since the nitrogen one-minus anion has a complete 2p orbital with electrons of opposite spin while nitrogen does not, the former is energetically unfavorable by this principle and therefore has negative electron affinity.
Walt Whitman’s poems “When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d” and “O Captain! My Captain” eulogize what 16th President of the United States?
George Saunders’ Lincoln in the Bardo won the 2017 edition of this prestigious prize, which is awarded to the best novel written in English each year.
“Abraham Lincoln Walks at Midnight” is by this poet who instructed a bass drum to be beaten at the beginning of his masterpiece “General William Booth Enters Into Heaven.”
